tweets.content:
The polls got it wrong, @Polymarket got it right AGAIN.

Before the Bolivian elections, polls had Jorge Quiroga as the favorite to win. But once voting began, Polymarket was already giving Rodrigo Paz a 57% chance to win.

Just a few hours later, without any major media updates, Paz's odds surged to 76% on Polymarket. Soon after, it was confirmed that Paz won.

Even more interesting: a suspicious fresh account placed a $100,000+ bet on Paz a few hours before the elections started. Given Bolivia's track record with corruption, I wouldn't be surprised if that guy knew something that we don't.

Polymarket called the US elections, called the Nobel Prize winner hours before it was announced, and now predicted the Bolivian elections too.

The only source of truth.

Polymarket supercycle.

tweets.content:
Polymarket > News

I analyzed Polymarket with various media outlets based on Brier score
Polymarket recently published a page with its data on the accuracy and Brier score

I decided to compare several media outlets with polymarkets based on the Brier score.
I took media such as:

- Washington Post
- Fox Business
- Reuters
- MarketWatch
- ESPN

I used more than 15 different events published by various media outlets
Financial, sporting, and other events were used
Political events were excluded

Here is the result:

- Polymarket â€” 0.0581
- Washington Post â€” 0.0651
- Fox Business â€” 0.0681
- Reuters â€” 0.0736
- MarketWatch â€” 0.1496
- ESPN â€” 0.2551

As you can see, Polymarket surpasses all media outlets in the accuracy of its predictions

Then the question is: "Why use the news?"

There is no longer any need for that
Polymarket has 91.1% accuracy
Here you will learn about all events much earlier

News is the past

Always use only @Polymarket

tweets.content:
Prediction markets are supposed to give you probabilities, not outcomes. The real world is uncertain, and @Polymarket quantifies that uncertainty with probabilities.

So if it's not "Polymarket predicted X and X did/didn't happened"â€”if it just outputs probabilitiesâ€”how do you measure how predictive Polymarket actually is? 

Statisticians already have a tool for this, called the Brier Score. Brier Scores basically tell you: "when you say an outcome is ~60% likely to happen, do those things happen 60% of the time?" Same for 10%, same for 90%, and so on.

Here's what that looks like for Polymarket, @Dune dashboard by @alexmccullaaa ğŸ‘‡

For Brier Scores, smaller is better. Anything below 0.1 is generally fantastic. (Sports betting lines tend to be around 0.2). Polymarket's Brier Score is 0.056, which means it is extremely accurate at surfacing correct probabilities.

Takeaway: Polymarket is very accurate, but it's subtle what that means and how it's measured.

tweets.author: Polymarket

tweets.content:
As prediction markets like @Polymarket move further into the mainstream, theyâ€™re evolving into a new class of macro indicators that complement traditional asset data.

For instance, when tracking U.S.â€“China trade dynamics, traders now watch not only soybeans, Treasuries/CGBs, USD/CNH, and the Rare Earth Index â€” but also the pricing of related contracts on prediction platforms.

Horizontal opportunity:
If liquidity and market depth continue to grow, and these markets reach greater informational efficiency, prediction markets could enable cross-asset and cross-venue arbitrage. In essence, they sit at the frontier of macro option-implied expectations â€” adding a new dimension to inter-market relative-value strategies.

Vertical opportunity:
When prediction markets remain inefficient, investors can instead target gaps between institutional positioning and speculative sentiment, finding arbitrage opportunities within a single market through differences in expectations.

tweets.author: Polymarket

tweets.content:
I turned a $25 Polymarket deposit into $26,664 PnL. Here is the journey:

I was watching election night live and saw Polymarket in action. Soon after, I deposited ~$25, placed a few bets, then basically forgot about it. Two months later I checked back and the small account had doubled.

That's when I dug a bit deeper into the platform and discovered Polymarket rewards for providing liquidity. I experimented with placing limit orders in illiquid markets when I was bored. Over ~3 months (while barely active), I turned the ~$50 into ~$1,200: about -$200 from trades but +$1,400 from rewards.

Then I decided to actually trade. I joined some Discord servers and talked to new people (I also started separate Polymarket accounts). During the action-packed June (US-Israel strikes on Iran), I grew the $1,200 into $10,000 in just 33 days.

After that, I went mostly inactive for 50 days, only placing the occasional bet. PnL stayed flat with small spikes.

In mid-August I started actively trading again. In the ~50 days since, I've grown the account to $26,664 PnL.

For transparency: I've traded crypto before and now run multiple Polymarket accounts (though these aren't included in the PnL here). I could have redeposited funds at any time, but I still followed strict risk management (no single bet over 20% of the portfolio). There were also some non-trade transactions (refunds, alpha sharing, poker). I tried to keep these off this account to keep the portfolio size clean, but they probably nudged the numbers slightly.

So while I called it "$25 to $26,664," the more accurate description is a $1k to $27k run in 4-5 months of trading. But since my name is 25usdc, I'll have to stick with the first version.

Going forward, I'll use this account to share opinions on bets, updates on my trades, and my ongoing journey in prediction markets. Next milestone: $100k. Let's see how far this $25 can go.

tweets.content:
Polymarkets on everything ğŸ”® 

So incredible to see ICE (the owner of @NYSE) invest $2 billion into @Polymarket, & share that @foundersfund led a $150 million round earlier this year. 

When we first invested in 2023, we were excited that their volumes were picking up â€” at around $10 million per month. Theyâ€™ve now consistently been doing over $1 billion in volume per month, and last month did over $1.4 billion. We believe @shayne_coplan and team are building a true zero-to-one product â€” effectively a new financial instrument â€” in an early yet blossoming new market. And Polymarketâ€™s partnership with ICE will only continue to drive prediction markets (as well as other exciting collaborations between the two, like tokenization) to the mainstream. Metamask & others are also planning to integrate Polymarket markets directly into their UI.

Polymarket was Joey and Iâ€™s first crypto growth deal, as well as our first consumer crypto investment. We have watched Shayne & team effectively will a new category into existence, and keep 100% conviction (even during tough times) that prediction markets built via defi would be generational. Their product obsession + pulse on culture + creativity & execution is so impressive.

Lastly: it's worth noting that @joeykrug has believed in prediction markets for over a decade, and actually built the first decentralized one â€” Augur â€” on Ethereum in 2014 (before Ethereum even had stablecoins). His vision was prescient, and we are thrilled to see prediction markets come to life via Polymarket.
